text: is there an OEIS like db for dynamical systems (not necessarily in julia)? often i find my self googling "X dynamics" and then searching thru either wiki or research papers to get the model. itd be nice to be able to do this and get back a DE.jl problem

elements.text: is there an OEIS like db for dynamical systems (not necessarily in julia)? often i find my self googling "X dynamics" and then searching thru either wiki or research papers to get the model. itd be nice to be able to do this and get back a DE.jl problem

text:
This would actually be a really interesting project.
You give it a dump of your (noisy) data and it tries to fit it against indexed systems (maybe ReservoirComputing+ other technologies).
It shows you similar systems, generalizations whether something projects down to something else. Where it is used. What parameter ranges result in this behavior and Julia code.
That might be a really good way to get citations. OEIS has 8700+ citations.
I only see the problem that identifying dynamical systems is (way) more expensive than indexing sequences.

Is this something people would pay for to have more features/longer computation time?

text: BTW the name OEDS (on-line enclyclopedia of dynamical systems) isn't taken by something with high google weight.
haha i was thinking the same thing!
